study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether P. crocatum extract affects IL-10 levels, TGF-β1 and VEGF expression, collagen density, and wound healing in Wistar rats after mammary tumor excision.
results_summary: P. crocatum extract decreased IL-10 levels and TGF-β1 expression, increased VEGF expression, and reduced collagen density in post-excision wounds of Wistar rats. The study suggests the extract influences wound healing through these mechanisms.
population_specificity: Female Wistar rats with induced mammary tumors.
effective_dosage: Red betel extract gel at concentrations of 50%, 25%, and 12.5%, applied twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize lung-infiltrating monocytes/macrophages in a mouse model of RA-ILD and determine whether reducing these cells mitigates lung disease.
results_summary: The study found that dual exposure to collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) and LPS induced unique activated macrophage subpopulations and lung disease, which was attenuated by reducing circulating monocytes. The immunophenotype of interstitial macrophages aligned more with CIA than LPS alone.
population_specificity: Autoimmune-prone DBA/1J mice.
effective_dosage: Not specified for collagen (CIA induction method not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an in-depth review of collagen-based micro/nanogels, focusing on their manufacturing technologies, drug release mechanisms, and biomedical applications.
results_summary: The study highlights the versatility of collagen-based micro/nanogels in biomedical applications, including cancer therapy, antimicrobial treatments, bone tissue repair, and imaging diagnosis, due to their tunable properties and environmental responsiveness. It also discusses challenges and future perspectives for clinical translation.
population_specificity: Not specified (review article)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the progression and treatment outcomes of corneal collagen crosslinking (CXL) in older patients (aged over 50) with post-LASIK ectasia.
results_summary: Postoperative flattening of steep keratometry (K2) and improvement in visual acuity were observed in all patients, with no reported complications, supporting CXL's effectiveness in this population.
population_specificity: Patients aged 51-73 years with post-LASIK ectasia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (epithelium-off CXL using the Dresden protocol).
study_duration: Follow-up ranged from 3 to 5 years post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the impact of neferine on ankle joint inflammation and cardiac complications in collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) mice.
results_summary: Neferine alleviated ankle joint inflammation, cartilage erosion, and bone destruction, reduced inflammatory cytokines, and mitigated myocardial injury and fibrosis in CIA mice by inhibiting NF-κB/NLRP3 inflammasome activation.
population_specificity: Male DBA/1 mice with collagen-induced arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of new collagen-based products in wound healing compared to commercial products in a murine model.
results_summary: After 18 days, animals treated with new collagen (Hy-C and N-C) showed accelerated wound closure, increased epithelialization, and more organized granulation tissue compared to untreated wounds. Significant differences in contraction were observed between control and the N-C and Helix3-CP groups after 7 days.
population_specificity: 72 Wistar rats with cutaneous excisional defects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of in situ collagen injections as a minimally invasive treatment for symptomatic neuroma in an elderly patient with postamputation pain.
results_summary: The study found that collagen injections significantly reduced pain and improved functional outcomes for up to 4 weeks, though the effects diminished by the 12-week follow-up. The treatment was well-tolerated and showed potential as a safe alternative to more invasive interventions.
population_specificity: An 87-year-old patient with a longstanding transfemoral amputation and symptomatic neuroma.
effective_dosage: 2 ultrasound-guided perineuromal injections of a porcine-derived collagen medical device, administered 3 days apart.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of collagen peptides on acetic acid-induced colitis in rats, focusing on inflammation, tissue damage, and intestinal barrier integrity.
results_summary: Collagen peptides significantly improved disease activity scores, reduced colon damage, restored intestinal barrier integrity, and decreased inflammatory markers, with effects comparable to Saccharomyces boulardii.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats with acetic acid-induced colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of a collagen matrix (VXCM) versus a connective tissue graft (SCTG) in increasing soft tissue thickness around dental implants.
results_summary: The collagen matrix (VXCM) showed greater soft tissue gain at 3 months post-op compared to SCTG, but SCTG outperformed VXCM at 6 months. Patient-reported outcomes favored VXCM, while aesthetic results favored SCTG.
population_specificity: Patients with a single tooth gap and horizontal soft tissue thickness deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an antimicrobial barrier composed of native type I collagen and polyhexamethylene biguanide (PCMP) could protect MRSA-infected wounds and support progression through the wound healing cascade.
results_summary: PCMP-treated wounds showed significantly lower MRSA levels and achieved 90% closure by 2 weeks, while untreated controls exhibited dampened immune responses. Removal of PCMP before wound closure led to a resurgence in bioburden.
population_specificity: Porcine wound model infected with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA).
effective_dosage: Not specified (PCMP applied for varying durations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of Collagen/V2CTx composite aerogels for oil absorption and wastewater treatment.
results_summary: The COL/V2CTx aerogel demonstrated high oil absorption capacity (up to 54 times its weight for methylene chloride), excellent mechanical properties (83 kPa compressive stress at 70% strain), low density (25 mg/cm³), and good thermal stability (58.67% weight loss from 240℃ to 600℃).
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop collagen-targeted drug delivery systems to improve the therapeutic potential of anti-fibrotic treatments in mouse models of lung and kidney fibrosis.
results_summary: The study identified and validated two collagen-targeting drug delivery systems (VWF-A3 and CBP-micelles) that preferentially accumulated in fibrotic organs. These novel formulations showed improved efficacy in mouse models compared to untargeted drugs.
population_specificity: Mouse models of lung and kidney fibrosis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the healing outcomes of venous leg ulcers (VLUs) treated with ovine forestomach matrix (OFM) versus collagen/oxidised regenerated cellulose (ORC) in a real-world patient cohort.
results_summary: The study found that OFM-treated VLUs had a higher incidence of closure at 12, 24, and 36 weeks, with significant differences at 24 and 36 weeks compared to collagen/ORC. Median time to wound closure was significantly faster in the OFM group (11.1 weeks) versus collagen/ORC (12.3 weeks), and OFM-treated VLUs had a ~40% greater probability of healing.
population_specificity: Patients with venous leg ulcers (VLUs) treated in outpatient wound care centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a collagen-based bone graft matrix enriched with human cell-derived BMP-2 (hBMP-2) for bone regeneration.
results_summary: The hBMP-2-enriched collagen graft showed improved bone regeneration parameters compared to the graft-only group, with enhanced new bone formation observed histologically, though statistical significance was limited.
population_specificity: Rat calvaria defect model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether belt electrode-skeletal muscle electrical stimulation (B-SES) could prevent muscle atrophy in collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) rats without worsening arthritis.
results_summary: B-SES prevented muscle atrophy in CIA rats by reducing muscle degradation markers (atrogin-1 and MuRF-1) without exacerbating arthritis, though it did not significantly affect muscle synthesis or mitochondrial markers.
population_specificity: 8-week-old male Dark Agouti rats with collagen-induced arthritis.
effective_dosage: B-SES (50 Hz) applied four times on the right hindlimb.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of epithelium-off corneal collagen crosslinking (CXL) under general anesthesia in patients with Down syndrome and keratoconus.
results_summary: The study found that CXL was well tolerated, with visual acuity stable or improved post-procedure. Complications were minimal, including one case of transient corneal edema and another of new apical scarring.
population_specificity: Patients with Down syndrome and keratoconus (34 eyes of 20 patients, mean age 20.2 years).
study_duration: Follow-up ranged from 1 week to over a year post-procedure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficiency of amniotic membrane, collagen membrane, and buccal fat pad in treating oral submucous fibrosis (OSMF) patients.
results_summary: The study found that amniotic membrane grafts were more effective than buccal fat pad flaps and collagen membranes in reducing discomfort, improving mouth opening, and promoting epithelisation in OSMF patients. Collagen membranes were less effective compared to amniotic membranes.
population_specificity: 30 patients diagnosed with OSMF, divided equally into three treatment groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of DWN12088, a selective PRS inhibitor, in preventing keloid development by targeting collagen biosynthesis.
results_summary: The study found that PRS was overexpressed in keloid fibroblasts and tissues, and a selective PRS inhibitor effectively downregulated fibrotic markers, reduced collagen production, and suppressed keloid formation in a mouse model.
population_specificity: Patient-derived keloid fibroblasts (KFs) and keloid tissues, tested in a KF xenograft SCID mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a micro-fragmented collagen hydrogel wound dressing (MCWD) containing hADSCs for improving wound healing outcomes compared to conventional methods.
results_summary: The MCWD demonstrated superior cell viability, cytokine production, and therapeutic outcomes in vitro and in vivo, including enhanced cell proliferation, skin thickness restoration, collagen maturation, and blood vessel formation compared to conventional cell aggregates and collagen hydrogel dressings.
population_specificity: Human Adipose-derived stem cells (hADSCs) and wound healing models (in vitro and in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the synergy between hyaluronic acid (HA) and collagen (COL) in neural-specific applications for repair, regeneration, and recovery, focusing on biomimetic scaffolds for neural tissue regeneration.
results_summary: The study found that HA-COL based scaffolds create a favorable microenvironment for stem cell migration, proliferation, and survival, promoting neural regeneration. Collagen contributes to healing CNS injuries, while HA regulates cellular activities, enhancing neural repair.
population_specificity: Neural regeneration applications (not specified for human or animal models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate heat-induced collagen-triglyceride complex formation, identify pyrazine-binding residues, and assess implications for flavor retention strategies.
results_summary: Heating stabilized collagen-triglyceride complexes via hydrogen bonds, van der Waals forces, and covalent bonds, showing high affinity for specific pyrazines. Molecular docking revealed key binding residues, enhancing thermal stability while destabilizing hydrogen networks.
population_specificity: In vitro collagen-triglyceride-pyrazine model (no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of type I collagen versus Matrigel as an extracellular matrix for bacterial colonisation in organoids to model bacterial cancer therapy.
results_summary: Type I collagen demonstrated a more than 5-times greater initial infection efficiency and supported over a 10-fold expansion of bacterial cell numbers within 4 days compared to Matrigel. The study suggests collagen is superior for bacterial colonisation in organoid models of cancer therapy.
population_specificity: Preclinical organoid models (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a combination of IGF1-rich exosomes, silk fibroin, and collagen hydrogel could effectively treat annulus fibrosus wounds and inhibit intervertebral disk degeneration.
results_summary: The study found that IGF1 and IGF1-rich exosomes promoted the proliferation and migration of annulus fibrosus cells, and the SF-collagen hydrogel accelerated wound healing, maintained IVD height, and reduced degeneration in rats.
population_specificity: Rats with annulus fibrosus wounds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of a sodium hyaluronate microneedle patch containing hardystonite bioceramic (ZnCS/MN) for repairing UVB-induced photodamaged skin, focusing on its anti-ROS, anti-inflammatory, and anti-collagen degradation effects.
results_summary: The study found that ZnCS/MN effectively delivered bioactive ions to photodamaged skin, reducing ROS, inflammation, and collagen degradation, and showed promise for clinical application due to its preparation and storage advantages.
population_specificity: Not specified (implied to be in vitro or animal models based on abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare cartilage defects and patient characteristics between the initial 1,000 and subsequent 5,000 patients treated with MACI (matrix-induced autologous chondrocyte implantation) to assess consistency in treatment utilization and outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that MACI utilization remained consistent, with comparable patient demographics and concomitant surgical procedures between the two groups. Patellofemoral defects were the most treated, and an overall low rate of adverse events was observed, though defect sizes were larger in the subsequent 5,000 patients.
population_specificity: Adults (mean age 33.6 years) with cartilage defects, primarily in the knee (5,198 knees treated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a temperature-responsive hydrogel containing recombinant type III collagen (rCol III) could effectively prevent intrauterine adhesions (IUA) and promote endometrial regeneration.
results_summary: The rCol III hydrogel demonstrated favorable biocompatibility, promoted endometrial stromal cell recruitment, reduced fibrosis, and enhanced angiogenesis. In vivo, it improved endometrial regeneration, blood supply, and reduced fibrin deposition compared to a commercial hyaluronate gel.
population_specificity: Sexually mature female rats with induced IUA.

study_goal: To compare the clinical efficacy of epithelium-off and transepithelial accelerated corneal collagen crosslinking (ACXL) in treating adolescent keratoconus.
results_summary: Both epithelium-off and transepithelial ACXL effectively treated keratoconus, with transepithelial ACXL showing slight inferiority in maximum corneal curvature but superiority in improving corneal thickness and deformation amplitude parameters. No differences were observed in other parameters before or after treatment.
population_specificity: 60 patients aged 16-26 years with keratoconus (60 eyes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve collagen fiber detection in undergrowth fibers, particularly in spinal cord injury (SCI), using a fingerprint enhancement (FP-E) algorithm.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that the FP-E algorithm effectively tracked changes in collagen organization over time, showing a significant increase in fiber density in SCI samples. The method was simpler and less time-consuming than existing techniques, suggesting potential for collagen as a biomarker in diseases with developing fibers.
population_specificity: Injured spinal cord samples (animal or human not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a hydrogel integrating human extracellular matrix-like collagen (hCol) to enhance soft tissue regeneration by modulating immune responses, cellular differentiation, and anti-aging processes.
results_summary: The hydrogel demonstrated rapid and sustained regenerative efficacy, with repair rates of 95.2% at 3 months and 76.2% at 6 months in clinical trials for mandibular retrognathia. The hydrogel effectively reshaped the soft tissue microenvironment, supporting immediate repair and sustained regeneration.
population_specificity: Patients with mandibular retrognathia (clinical trials) and animal models (preclinical studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical effects of entecavir monotherapy versus entecavir + thymalfasin combination therapy on serum markers (HA, LN, IVC) and liver function in HBeAG-positive chronic hepatitis B patients.
results_summary: The combination therapy group showed lower levels of HA, LN, and IVC, improved immune function, and better liver function markers (TBIL, ALT) compared to the monotherapy group, with statistically significant differences (P<0.05).
population_specificity: HBeAG-positive chronic hepatitis B patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiarthritic effects of remdesivir in a mouse model of collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) and in fibroblast-like synoviocytes from RA patients.
results_summary: Remdesivir suppressed arthritis incidence and progression in CIA mice, reduced inflammation and cartilage damage, and inhibited pro-inflammatory cytokine expression and Th17 cell differentiation. In vitro, it suppressed STING, NF-κB, and necroptosis markers in RA-FLSs under TNF-α stimulation.
population_specificity: DBA/1J mice with collagen-induced arthritis and fibroblast-like synoviocytes from RA patients.
effective_dosage: Subcutaneous injection three times a week (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the expression and localization of the α3 chain of type V collagen in the skin, its changes during aging, and its modulation by retinoic acid and interaction with MMP-9.
results_summary: The study found that α3(V) collagen is produced by basal skin keratinocytes and decreases with age. Retinoic acid treatment increased α3(V) collagen expression, and its inhibition led to higher MMP-9 expression, suggesting potential therapeutic and anti-aging benefits.
population_specificity: Ex vivo skin samples and keratinocytes from donors of different ages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate collagen sheets as a reconstruction option for soft tissue deficits following surgical removal of dysplastic red and white oral lesions.
results_summary: The study found that collagen sheets are an excellent reconstruction option for concealing mucosal defects after surgical excision of dysplastic oral lesions. The abstract highlights their effectiveness in addressing soft tissue loss, particularly in cases with histologically verified dysplastic features.
population_specificity: Patients with histologically verified dysplastic red and white oral lesions requiring surgical excision.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a deep learning method to classify wound healing stages and delayed healing conditions based on collagen fiber patterns in histological images.
results_summary: The model achieved 85% accuracy in classifying five wound healing stages and 78% accuracy in identifying delayed healing, demonstrating that collagen fiber features effectively predict healing progression. The interpretable framework localized collagen regions as key drivers of model predictions.
population_specificity: Not specified (implied to involve skin tissue samples, potentially from animal or human models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a sequential theranostic platform for real-time monitoring of collagen clearance and targeted siRNA delivery to improve personalized therapy for pulmonary fibrosis.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that collagen-targeting and degrading with MRI-guided siRNA delivery significantly enhanced lesion enrichment and therapeutic efficacy in pulmonary fibrosis treatment. The approach allowed real-time monitoring of collagen clearance and optimized siRNA delivery timing.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary fibrosis (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: To determine if combining autologous platelet-rich plasma (aPRP) and rosuvastatin (RSV) enhances collagen type I and III immunoexpression, improving wound healing and tissue repair.
results_summary: Type I collagen immunoexpression was significantly higher in aPRP-treated wounds compared to controls, while type III collagen was predominant during the proliferation phase, suggesting its critical role in tissue repair. The combination of aPRP and RSV may have an additive effect on type III collagen immunoexpression.
population_specificity: Eight clinically healthy adult male New Zealand rabbits.
study_duration: Analyzed up to 14 days post wound induction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the types, sources, synthesis, degradation, and advancements of collagen in bone regeneration, as well as its potential clinical applications.
results_summary: The study found that collagen is a promising alternative for bone regeneration due to its biocompatibility, low immunogenicity, and ability to transport nutrients or drugs. It highlighted collagen's potential in various forms like scaffolds, sponges, and hydrogels for therapeutic strategies.
population_specificity: Individuals with bone deficiencies caused by injuries, ailments, congenital abnormalities, or cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether a novel bovine dermal collagen matrix (BDCM) could reduce the time required to develop tissue for autografting in full-thickness wounds compared to other dermal matrices.
results_summary: BDCM-treated wounds showed significantly higher autograft take (96.88%) at seven days compared to other matrices (ColGAG: 85%, FSG: 68%), with less wound contraction and better cellular infiltration and angiogenesis. The results suggest BDCM accelerates tissue readiness for autografting with high consistency.
population_specificity: Yorkshire pigs with surgically created full-thickness excisional wounds.
study_duration: 7 days post-matrix application, followed by 35 days post-autografting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical examination, radiographic measurements, and MRI findings to determine criteria for surgical intervention in COL2-associated atlantoaxial instability (AAI) in skeletal dysplasia patients.
results_summary: The study identified 7 criteria (e.g., hyperreflexia, radiographic os odontoid, myelomalacia) that indicate surgical intervention, with patients having ≥4 criteria showing an 80% likelihood of surgery recommendation. Nonoperative management was effective for patients with ≤1 criteria.
population_specificity: Patients with skeletal dysplasias (particularly COL2 mutations), majority female (54%) and white (80%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether alendronate (ALN) pretreatment could promote biomimetic mineralization of type I collagen fibrils and demineralized dentin.
results_summary: ALN pretreatment facilitated intrafibrillar mineralization of type I collagen fibrils in a dose-dependent manner and restored the mechanical properties of demineralized dentin to levels comparable to natural dentin when used with polyelectrolyte-stabilized ACP nanoparticles.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on collagen fibrils and demineralized dentin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of type I collagen, alone or combined with olfactory ensheathing cells, in treating chronic spinal cord injury in rats.
results_summary: Collagen hydrogel (1 and 4 mg/ml) reduced cyst volume, restored hindlimb motor function, and stimulated remyelination of damaged nerve tissue, with or without olfactory ensheathing cells. The results suggest promise for further study of collagen-based treatments for spinal cord injuries.
population_specificity: Rats with chronic spinal cord injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in type 1 collagen in the lungs of participants with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) following treatment with bexotegrast, a dual-selective inhibitor of αvβ6 and αvβ1 integrins.
results_summary: Bexotegrast treatment resulted in reduced uptake of 68Ga-CBP8 in the lungs, indicating an antifibrotic effect, along with numerical improvements in lung microvasculature, forced vital capacity (FVC), cough severity, and biomarker levels compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Adults with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether IGF-I stimulates or reduces fibrosis in the liver by studying its effects on collagen accumulation and degradation in hepatic stellate cells (HSCs).
results_summary: IGF-I treatment reduced collagen deposition in a dose-related manner, upregulated MMP-2 and -9 expression, and downregulated TIMP-1 expression via an mTOR-dependent pathway, without affecting TGF-beta levels or type I procollagen mRNA expression.
population_specificity: Moderately activated hepatic stellate cells (HSCs) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether collagen-based hydrogels derived from amniotic membrane (AMCh) encapsulated with SDF-1α microspheres could enhance diabetic wound healing in rats.
results_summary: The study found that AMCh + SDF-1α microspheres significantly improved wound closure, collagen density, blood vessel formation, and reduced inflammatory markers compared to untreated diabetic rats, with the most pronounced effects in the AMCh + SM group.
population_specificity: Diabetic rats (animal model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lymphomonocytic-derived extracellular vesicles (EVs) influence fibroblast proliferation and collagen synthesis in systemic sclerosis (SSc).
results_summary: EVs from PMA + IONO-stimulated immune cells significantly reduced fibroblast proliferation and collagen production in both healthy and SSc-derived fibroblasts, while TNFα-stimulated EVs only affected healthy fibroblasts.
population_specificity: Fibroblasts from healthy donors (HDFs) and systemic sclerosis patients (SScHDFs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare two animal models of systemic sclerosis (bleomycin-induced fibrosis and collagen-V-induced autoimmune) to evaluate their ability to replicate key disease features.
results_summary: The bleomycin model showed consistent cardiac fibrosis but variability in skin and lung fibrosis, while the collagen-V model demonstrated robust autoantibody production against collagen-V with fibrosis mainly in the heart. Both models highlighted the dynamic nature of fibrosis and the relevance of cardiac fibrosis in systemic sclerosis pathophysiology.
population_specificity: Animal models (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a novel collagen-infused natural rubber latex (NRL-C) dressing for treating diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs).
results_summary: The NRL-C dressing promoted angiogenesis, stimulated fibroblast and keratinocyte proliferation, accelerated wound closure, and demonstrated biocompatibility in rodent models. A pilot clinical trial involving six diabetic patients showed promising therapeutic outcomes.
population_specificity: Diabetic patients with foot ulcers (rodent models and a small human pilot study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of exosome-derived human mesenchymal stem cells (EH-MSCs) on oxidative stress (MDA) and inflammation (MMP-1) in UVB-irradiated rats.
results_summary: EH-MSCs significantly reduced MDA and MMP-1 levels in UVB-irradiated rats, indicating potent antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects. The results were statistically significant (p < 0.05) and dose-dependent.
population_specificity: UVB-irradiated Wistar rats
effective_dosage: 200 μL and 300 μL subcutaneous injections of EH-MSCs

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of a novel recombinant human collagen hydrogel loaded with different MSC-derived exosomes for wound healing.
results_summary: The study found that the exosome-loaded collagen hydrogels significantly improved cell proliferation, migration, and wound healing in rats, with umbilical cord MSC-exos showing the best therapeutic performance.
population_specificity: Rats with wounds (animal model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether targeting collagen (specifically COL1A1) could remodel the ECM to enhance chemosensitivity in ovarian cancer.
results_summary: The study found that COL1A1 contributes to chemoresistance and poor prognosis in ovarian cancer. Halofuginone (HF) inhibited COL1A1 production, disrupted collagen deposition, and promoted CD8+ T cell infiltration, enhancing chemosensitivity.
population_specificity: Ovarian cancer patients (based on single-cell RNA-seq data and analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of Tm4sf19 in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) using a collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) mouse model and evaluate the effects of LEL-Fc as a potential treatment.
results_summary: Inhibition of Tm4sf19 by LEL-Fc showed preventive and therapeutic effects in CIA mice, reducing inflammation, cartilage damage, and bone destruction. LEL-Fc also suppressed inflammatory signaling in macrophages and disrupted interactions between Tm4sf19, TLR4, and MD2.
population_specificity: CIA-induced mice (animal model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the temporomandibular intradiscal junction is the initiation site for discal degeneration and how mechanical stimuli affect collagen properties in this region.
results_summary: The study found that the intradiscal junction showed early signs of degeneration, including reduced collagen fibril diameter and increased denatured procollagen, mediated by mechanical stimuli involving tenascin-C and metalloproteinase-3. Early repositioning of the disc blocked these degenerative changes, preserving mechanical function.
population_specificity: Rabbit models of anterior disc displacement-mediated temporomandibular osteoarthritis.
study_duration: Observations began as early as one week post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of recombinant humanized collagen (rhCol III) in promoting extracellular matrix (ECM) remodeling and angiogenesis for pelvic organ prolapse (POP) treatment.
results_summary: rhCol III enhanced fibroblast proliferation, migration, and ECM synthesis in POP tissues, increased collagen expression in a rat model, and improved angiogenesis in vitro and in vivo.
population_specificity: Vaginal wall tissues from non-POP (3) and POP (5) patients, and a simulated birth injury rat model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between the tumor microenvironment collagen score, immunoscore, and lymph node metastasis in colon cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that the collagen score and immunoscore were independent risk factors for lymph node metastasis in colon cancer, with the new model (including these factors) showing better predictive performance than traditional clinicopathological models.
population_specificity: 249 colon cancer patients who underwent laparoscopic-assisted D3 lymphadenectomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the roles of various collagen types in tumor development, progression, prognosis, and their potential as therapeutic targets across multiple cancer types.
results_summary: The study reviewed collagen's involvement in tumor biology, including tumorigenesis, invasion, migration, drug resistance, and recurrence, as well as its role in prognostic assessments, therapeutic efficacy evaluation, immunoregulation, and treatment target identification. It differentiated tumors based on collagen types and explored their implications in oncology.
population_specificity: Various tumor types, including lung, gastric, breast, melanoma, and colorectal cancers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of TachoSil® collagen fleece as a graft for correcting residual curvature during penile prosthesis implantation in patients with Peyronie's disease.
results_summary: The study found that TachoSil® is a reliable and robust graft with excellent results, demonstrating safety and effectiveness for residual curvature correction. The technique is described as safe, though more long-term follow-up data are requested.
population_specificity: Patients with Peyronie's disease and co-existing erectile dysfunction not responding to medical/conservative treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a culture-platform to study human ovarian fibrosis and test antifibrotic drugs (Pirfenidone, Metformin, Mitoquinone) to reduce or reverse excess collagen content in ovarian tissue.
results_summary: The study found that anti-inflammatory and antioxidant drugs, particularly Metformin, reduced and reverted excess collagen in ovarian cortical tissue, exerted antioxidant effects, prevented glycolytic metabolic shifts, and promoted early folliculogenesis.
population_specificity: Transmasculine donors of reproductive age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of SINX, a derivative of sinomenine, in treating bone destruction in rheumatoid arthritis using a collagen-induced arthritis mouse model.
results_summary: SINX demonstrated strong anti-inflammatory and bone-protective effects, inhibiting osteoclast differentiation, reducing joint inflammation, and preserving bone density in the CIA mouse model. It also activated antioxidant pathways, achieving similar results to sinomenine at lower doses.
population_specificity: Collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects and mechanisms of Norwogonin on inflammatory osteolysis in rheumatoid arthritis (RA), particularly in collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) mice.
results_summary: Norwogonin inhibited LPS-driven osteoclast differentiation and function, suppressed ROS production and calcium oscillations, and mitigated arthritis progression and bone destruction in CIA mice. The study identified key targets and pathways involved in Norwogonin's anti-osteoclastogenic effects.
population_specificity: Collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) mice.
effective_dosage: 30 mg/kg every other day (in vivo), 160 μM (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of biosynthetic glutaraldehyde-modified ovine collagen grafts (Omniflow II) and cryopreserved arterial homografts for treating infrainguinal vascular graft infections.
results_summary: The study found that Omniflow II grafts had a 97.1% freedom from reinfection rate and 50% primary patency at 5 years, with no graft degeneration or ruptures observed, suggesting similar efficacy to cryopreserved arterial homografts.
population_specificity: Patients with infrainguinal vascular graft infections treated between 2009 and 2019.

study_goal: To evaluate the safety and effectiveness of varenicline solution nasal spray (VNS) in reducing dry eye disease symptoms after corneal collagen cross-linking (CXL).
results_summary: VNS showed a non-significant improvement in dry eye symptoms and a trend toward faster corneal epithelial healing compared to the control group. Adverse events were mild and resolved without complications.
population_specificity: Subjects undergoing corneal collagen cross-linking (CXL).
study_duration: 56 days (28 days pre-procedure and 28 days post-procedure).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the osteogenic, anti-apoptotic, and antioxidant properties of collagen peptide UU1 (GASGPMGPR) for potential anti-osteoporosis applications.
results_summary: UU1 promoted osteogenic differentiation by elevating markers like ALP, Cyclin D1, Runx2, and Akt/β-catenin signaling, while also demonstrating anti-apoptotic effects via increased p-Akt levels and reduced Bax/Bcl-2 ratio. Molecular docking suggested UU1 may facilitate EGFR dimerization and activate collagen-binding integrin.
population_specificity: MC3T3-E1 cells (pre-osteoblastic cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the dynamic mechanism of collagen fibril remodeling from free orientation to high orientation and its relation to cancer cell invasion.
results_summary: The study found that mechanical forces from interstitial flow and cell deformation, as well as enzymes, significantly contribute to collagen fibril remodeling. Interstitial flow combined with enzymes was particularly effective in remodeling distal collagen fibrils near tumors.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro microfluidic chip-based model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a functional snack enriched with hydrolyzed collagen using various impregnation and drying technologies to enhance collagen content and bioaccessibility.
results_summary: The study found that vacuum impregnation (VI) achieved the highest collagen bioaccessibility (~90%), while MP-RW drying preserved more polyphenols and improved texture and sensory qualities. RW treatments also better-maintained color and crispness.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely general population, as the focus was on food product development).
effective_dosage: Not specified (collagen content reported as 79.86 g/100 g db in MP-I treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the biological functions and molecular mechanisms of recombinant human-like COL17A1 (rhCOL17) in skin epithelial cells, focusing on its role in epidermal-dermal attachment and potential antiaging applications.
results_summary: The study found that rhCOL17 interacts with collagens, integrins, and cell polarity proteins, upregulating laminin-332, integrin β1, PAR-3, and PAR-6B while activating PRKCZ, AKT, and TGF-β1 signaling pathways. It also promoted cell proliferation and mitigated UV-induced damage.
population_specificity: HaCaT cells (human keratinocyte cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a collagen-based scaffold (CTS) combined with adipose mesenchymal stem cell-derived exosomes could accelerate wound healing in diabetic rats.
results_summary: The study found that the combination of CTS and exosomes significantly improved wound closure rates, tissue regeneration, collagen density, and biomechanical parameters, with the greatest effects observed in the CTS+Exo group. Additionally, the treatment upregulated beneficial genes (miRNA-146a, TGF-β, bFGF, VEGF) and reduced inflammatory markers (TNF-α, IL-1β) and neutrophil counts.
population_specificity: Diabetic rats with induced wounds.
study_duration: Evaluations were conducted on days 7, 14, and 21 post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review research, innovation, and technological advancements related to marine invertebrate collagens and their applications.
results_summary: The study found renewed interest in marine invertebrate collagens since 2008, with key applications in regenerative medicine, hydrolysates, and biology. Market trends indicate growing demand for marine collagens in cosmetics and personalized nutrition.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature and patents).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of using a buccal fat pad with a collagen membrane as an alternative treatment for oral submucous fibrosis (OSMF).
results_summary: The study found a significant mean gain in mouth opening (5.29 ± 2.11 mm) and a significant reduction in pain levels (2.62 ± 1.05), with no complications or recurrence observed during the four-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Eight patients diagnosed with oral submucous fibrosis (OSMF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of collagen hydrolysate (CH) and dairy protein (DP) on recovery from exercise-induced muscle damage (EIMD) in recreationally active males.
results_summary: The study found that neither CH nor DP improved indices of EIMD during the acute recovery period, with no significant differences between the two protein sources. Downhill running induced significant muscle damage, but protein supplementation did not mitigate these effects.
population_specificity: Recreationally active males
study_duration: Acute recovery period (specific duration not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the relationship between probiotic supplementation and changes in bone mineral density (BMD) and bone turnover markers (BTMs), including collagen type 1 cross-linked C-telopeptide (CTX), in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Probiotic supplementation significantly increased BMD in the lumbar spine and hip and reduced levels of CTX and BALP, with more pronounced effects in women with osteopenia than osteoporosis. No significant differences were found for other BTMs.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (n=1183)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the impact of magnesium carbonate on bone mineral density and hemodynamic changes related to vascular calcification in CKD patients.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation increased urinary Mg excretion without altering serum Mg levels or causing hypermagnesemia. It was associated with improved vascular compliance (reduced PWV) but did not significantly affect bone mineral density or vascular calcification.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) stages 3-4.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) on inhibition of platelet aggregation and lipid profile in diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN) patients.
results_summary: ALA significantly inhibited collagen-induced and adenosine diphosphate-induced platelet aggregation and improved lipid profiles (reducing total cholesterol, LDL, VLDL, and triglycerides) over 12 weeks compared to placebo, with no serious adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Diabetic peripheral neuropathy patients (mean age 55.63 ± 7.5 years, 22 males and 30 females) on gabapentin or pregabalin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and expand upon the understanding of zinc's biological roles, including its involvement in collagen synthesis, and the health implications of zinc deficiency.
results_summary: The study highlights zinc's crucial role in physiological processes, including collagen synthesis, and links zinc deficiency to increased oxidative stress, inflammation, and disease pathogenesis. It emphasizes zinc's importance in immune regulation, cellular growth, and neurological health but does not specifically report collagen-related outcomes.
population_specificity: General biological and physiological processes (not specific to a human or animal population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-obesity effects of bovine collagen with enhanced water retention capacity, focusing on its ability to induce satiation and improve metabolic outcomes.
results_summary: Collagen supplementation significantly reduced body weight, BMI, fat mass, and blood pressure while increasing fat-free mass and satiation in overweight/obese individuals. It also showed low digestibility and high swelling capacity in vitro, along with reduced ghrelin levels in rats.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese humans (64 participants) and male Wistar rats.
effective_dosage: 20 g per day (via two protein bars).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of collagen peptide or hydrolyzed collagen supplementation on muscle damage, recovery, and construction related to physical exercise.
results_summary: The review found that collagen peptide supplementation may help mitigate muscle stress from acute strenuous resistance training, though methodological heterogeneity among studies calls for further clinical trials to clarify mechanisms.
population_specificity: Humans participating in randomized clinical trials (286 participants total, with 130 receiving collagen peptides and 171 receiving placebo/control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of oyster hydrolysate (OH) on UVB-induced skin aging in mice and its efficacy and safety in improving skin moisturization in humans.
results_summary: OH significantly reduced UVB-induced skin aging features, improved skin barrier function, and enhanced hydration in mice. The human clinical trial confirmed OH improved skin moisturization and integrity with no side effects.
population_specificity: SKH1 hairless mice and human participants in a clinical trial.
study_duration: 10 weeks for mice; human trial duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hydrolyzed collagen (HC) ingestion enhances collagen synthesis in response to resistance exercise (RE) in middle-aged men.
results_summary: The study found that 30 g of HC increased serum PINP concentration (a marker of collagen synthesis) more than 15 g, indicating a dose-response effect. No significant adverse effects were reported, but safety was not explicitly evaluated.
population_specificity: Eight resistance-trained middle-aged men (49 ± 8 years).
effective_dosage: 0 g, 15 g, or 30 g vitamin C-enriched HC.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the clinical efficacy of collagen-based supplements in improving knee osteoarthritis symptoms through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found statistically and clinically significant improvements in both function and pain scores for knee osteoarthritis patients taking collagen supplements compared to placebo. The results strongly favored collagen supplementation, with high statistical significance (p=0.00001).
population_specificity: 870 participants with knee osteoarthritis (451 in collagen group, 419 in placebo group) across 11 RCTs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of a collagen peptide dietary supplement on skin aging in the East Asian population.
results_summary: The study found that daily supplementation with 5 g of collagen peptides significantly improved dermis density, skin moisture, elasticity, wrinkle visibility, nail color, and overall beauty perception compared to placebo, with some effects observed as early as 28 days.
population_specificity: Healthy East Asian women aged 43–65 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hydrolyzed collagen peptide supplementation increases myofibrillar and muscle connective protein synthesis rates during intense resistance exercise training.
results_summary: Collagen peptide supplementation increased post-absorptive plasma glycine, proline, and hydroxyproline concentrations but did not enhance myofibrillar or muscle connective protein synthesis rates compared to placebo. Muscle connective protein synthesis rates were higher than myofibrillar rates in both groups, but collagen supplementation provided no additional benefit.
population_specificity: 25 young, recreational male athletes (24 ± 3 years, 76.9 ± 6.4 kg).
effective_dosage: 15 g hydrolyzed collagen peptides twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of long-term daily collagen peptide (CP) supplementation on strength, musculotendinous adaptation, functional recovery, and body composition in healthy adults, with and without exercise interventions.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in fat-free mass, tendon morphology, muscle architecture, maximal strength, and recovery in reactive strength following exercise-induced muscle damage, though the certainty of evidence ranged from low to moderate.
population_specificity: Healthy, normal to overweight adults over 17 years of age who engaged in exercise.
study_duration: Minimum of 8 weeks (except one 3-week trial for maximal strength)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of hydrolyzed collagen with vitamin C and its combination with hyaluronic acid on reducing signs of skin aging over 16 weeks.
results_summary: The study utilized validated methods to evaluate skin parameters, but specific results regarding efficacy were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Women aged 40-65 years.
effective_dosage: 5 g hydrolyzed collagen with 80 mg vitamin C daily (CP product) and its combination with 30 mg hyaluronic acid (CPHA product).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effects of hydrolyzed collagen supplementation on fibroblast proliferation and activation.
results_summary: Hydrolyzed collagens or collagen peptides at concentrations of 50-500 μg/mL stimulated fibroblasts in human and animal tissues without toxicity, with lower molecular weights showing greater bioavailability. Different enzymatic processes conferred distinct biological properties, favoring fibroblast promotion or antioxidant effects.
population_specificity: Human and animal tissues.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 12-week supplementation with specific collagen peptides (SCPs) reduces knee and hip pain in healthy adults over 18 years during daily activities.
results_summary: The study found that 5 g of SCP supplementation over 12 weeks significantly reduced pain at rest and during daily activities compared to placebo, as measured by a 10-point numeric rating scale.
population_specificity: Healthy men and women over 18 years with functional knee and hip pain during daily activities.
effective_dosage: 5 g of specific collagen peptides daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the anti-aging applications of marine collagen, focusing on its safety, efficacy, and mechanisms in combating skin aging.
results_summary: Marine collagen, particularly when enriched with amino acids like proline and glycine, demonstrated anti-aging benefits by reducing oxidative stress, photodamage, and wrinkles. Bioactive marine peptides showed diverse anti-aging properties, including free radical scavenging and lifespan extension.
population_specificity: Aging humans (general population, no specific subgroup mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of multispecies probiotic supplementation on bone turnover markers, specifically the C-terminal telopeptide of type I collagen (CTX), in postmenopausal women with osteopenia.
results_summary: The study found that the multispecies probiotic group had a slightly higher median serum CTX level compared to the placebo group, suggesting a potential effect on bone resorption, though the clinical significance is unclear.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with osteopenia (n=40).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily supplementation with L reuteri could reduce early postmenopausal bone loss and whether the effects persisted or increased over 2 years of treatment.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of L reuteri supplementation on bone loss or bone turnover markers over 2 years, with no group-to-group differences in tibia vBMD, hip and spine vBMD, or other predefined outcomes. A prespecified sensitivity analysis indicated a potential interaction between BMI and treatment effect, but no significant adverse effects were observed.
population_specificity: 239 early postmenopausal women (median age 55 years) in Gothenburg, Sweden.
effective_dosage: 5 × 10^8 (low dose) or 5 × 10^9 (high dose) colony-forming units, taken twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of high-functional Type J collagen peptides compared to conventional collagen peptides and placebo in improving symptoms of knee joint osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Type J collagen peptides at 2.5 g showed significant improvements in WOMAC, QoL, CTX-II, and MOAKS scores, with efficacy equivalent to conventional collagen peptides at 10 g. All tested dosages of Type J and conventional collagen peptides were beneficial for knee joint osteoarthritis.
population_specificity: Individuals with knee joint osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: 2.5 g, 5.0 g, and 10.0 g of Type J collagen peptides; 10.0 g of conventional collagen peptides; 10.0 g of placebo.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of hydrolyzed collagen alone or combined with fish oil on specific gut microbiome species in patients with major burns.
results_summary: Supplementation with collagen and omega-3 FAs prevented a significant reduction in gut Bifidobacterium, but no significant changes were observed in other bacteria measured. The Firmicutes to Bacteroidetes ratio decreased significantly in the collagen group.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-60 years with 20-45% total body surface area burns.
effective_dosage: 40 g hydrolyzed collagen + 10 ml sunflower oil or fish oil, divided into two daily drinks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of collagen, alone or combined with exercise, in improving pain, range of motion, strength, and function in recreational athletes with early osteoarthritic changes in the knee.
results_summary: The study found that all treatment groups, including collagen, showed improvement in activity-related pain (VAS), but no significant differences were observed between groups. Knee range of motion showed significant between-group differences, though specific collagen-related outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Recreational athletes with early osteoarthritic changes in the knee (n=48).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hydrolyzed collagen/vitamin C supplementation combined with progressive tendon loading exercises (PTLE) improves pain, function, and sports participation in athletes with patellar tendinopathy compared to PTLE with placebo.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, but the abstract suggests that hydrolyzed collagen/vitamin C supplementation combined with PTLE may have a promising effect on recovery from tendinopathy, though final efficacy results are pending.
population_specificity: Athletes aged 16-40 with patellar tendinopathy symptoms for at least 12 weeks, who play sports at least once weekly.
effective_dosage: 10 g hydrolyzed collagen and 40 mg vitamin C daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore collagen's role in skin photoaging and evaluate its potential for prevention and treatment.
results_summary: The study found that collagen and its derived peptides counteract photodamage-induced skin impairment by reducing collagen degradation and fragmentation caused by UV radiation. Supplementation with collagen effectively maintains skin structure and combats aging.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion on skin photoaging).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether consuming collagen protein above the RDA would enhance integrated muscle protein synthesis (MPS) rates in older males compared to whey and pea protein.
results_summary: Collagen supplementation did not increase integrated MPS rates, unlike whey and pea protein, which showed significant improvements. The study found no change in MPS with collagen despite increased postprandial aminoacidemia and anabolic signaling.
population_specificity: Healthy older males (72 ± 4 years)
effective_dosage: 50 g/day (25 g at breakfast and lunch)

study_goal: To determine the dose-response effect of hydrolyzed collagen (HC) ingestion on collagen synthesis after high-intensity resistance exercise in resistance-trained young men.
results_summary: Ingesting 30 g HC before high-intensity resistance exercise increased whole-body collagen synthesis more than 15 g or 0 g HC, as measured by serum PINP concentration. No significant differences were observed in β-CTX concentration or collagen amino acid levels between doses.
population_specificity: 10 resistance-trained young males (age 26 ± 3 years).
effective_dosage: 0 g, 15 g, or 30 g HC with 50 mg vitamin C, taken once before exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of collagens in pancreatic cell function, islet transplantation, and their potential implications in treating Type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) and collagen deposition-related pancreatic disorders.
results_summary: Collagens play a crucial role in pancreatic cell proliferation, survival, and function, and may enhance islet transplantation outcomes. However, excessive collagen deposition can lead to pancreatic fibrosis and carcinoma, suggesting a need for targeted inhibition strategies.
population_specificity: Pancreatic cells, immune cells, and implications for Type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of oral supplementation with collagen peptides rich in X-Hyp or X-Hyp-Gly on skin properties in healthy adults.
results_summary: The study found that collagen peptides enriched with X-Hyp or X-Hyp-Gly demonstrated resistance to digestive and systemic enzymes, suggesting potential for improved absorption efficiency and enhancement of skin properties. However, specific results regarding skin improvements were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 30 healthy adult participants aged between 22 and 30.
effective_dosage: 5 grams of collagen peptides or hydrolysates daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of collagen peptide supplementation combined with whey protein versus whey protein alone on muscle damage and recovery during eccentric exercise training.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in muscle damage indices or functional recovery between the whey protein + collagen peptide group and the whey protein-only group, despite improvements in performance metrics in both groups. Collagen peptide substitution did not enhance outcomes beyond whey protein alone.
population_specificity: Young fit males
effective_dosage: 20 g collagen peptides + 25 g whey protein daily (total 45 g protein)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining jump training with collagen supplementation could preserve or improve bone mineral density (BMD) in elite road-race cyclists.
results_summary: The study found that collagen supplementation combined with jump training preserved femoral neck BMD in cyclists, while the control group experienced a decline. No significant differences were observed in BMD at other skeletal sites or in bone turnover markers between groups.
population_specificity: 36 young (21 ± 3 years) male (n = 8) and female (n = 28) elite road-race cyclists.
effective_dosage: 15 g hydrolyzed collagen ingested before each of five weekly 5-minute jump training bouts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clinically evaluate the impact of low-molecular-weight collagen peptides on human skin parameters such as wrinkles, elasticity, hydration, and whitening.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in skin roughness, elasticity, hydration, and whitening in the test group compared to placebo, with no reported adverse events.
population_specificity: Healthy adult participants (n=100).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the osteogenic capacities of Osteo-F, a newly developed herbal formula, and its potential as a bone anabolic treatment for postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Osteo-F significantly enhanced bone matrix formation, mineralization, and collagen expression in osteoblasts, improved femoral BMD and osteocalcin levels in osteoporotic mice, and showed significant improvements in Z-score and serum osteocalcin levels in postmenopausal women compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if collagen peptide supplementation could enhance tendinous tissue adaptations (size and mechanical properties) in response to resistance training compared to a placebo.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between collagen peptide and placebo groups in tendinous tissue adaptations. Both groups showed similar within-group improvements in VL aponeurosis area, patellar tendon stiffness, and Young's modulus, but no between-group benefits from collagen supplementation.
population_specificity: Young healthy recreationally active men

study_goal: To determine the effects of daily collagen peptide (CP) consumption over 3, 6, and 9 months on pain, function, and physical and mental health in middle-aged active adults.
results_summary: The study found that 10 to 20 g/d of CP supplementation over 6 to 9 months improved activities of daily living (ADLs), pain, and mental and physical health scores in middle-aged active adults.
population_specificity: Middle-aged active adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of hydrolyzed collagen (HC) supplementation on skin hydration and elasticity through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: HC supplementation significantly improved skin hydration, as indicated by a strong test for overall effect (Z = 4.94). The study did not provide detailed results on skin elasticity in the abstract.
population_specificity: 1721 patients across 26 randomized controlled trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with specific collagen peptides enhances patellar tendon hypertrophy and related outcomes during high-load resistance training compared to placebo.
results_summary: The study found that 5g daily collagen peptide supplementation during 14 weeks of resistance training increased patellar tendon cross-sectional area (CSA) more than training alone, particularly in proximal and medial tendon sites. Training improved tendon stiffness, rectus femoris CSA, and knee extension strength, but these effects were independent of supplementation.
population_specificity: Individuals undergoing high-load resistance training (specific population details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of vitamin D supplementation on bone turnover markers (BTMs), including collagen-related markers like procollagen type I N-terminal propeptide (PINP) and collagen type 1 cross-linked C-telopeptide (CTX).
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation reduced deoxypyridinoline (DPD) and PINP levels, indicating decreased bone turnover, but had no significant effect on CTX or osteocalcin (OC). The effect on alkaline phosphatase (ALP) was pronounced when the intervention lasted >12 weeks.
population_specificity: Adults aged 19.4 to 84 years, with subgroup analysis for individuals aged >50 years.
study_duration: Varied, with notable effects observed in interventions lasting >12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of vitamin D supplementation on preventing airway remodeling in asthmatic patients, including its impact on collagen synthesis in the airways.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation was found to inhibit airway smooth muscle cell contraction and remodeling, reduce inflammation, regulate collagen synthesis, and modulate bronchial fibroblast action, though TGF-β1 may impair some of these effects.
population_specificity: Asthmatic patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 12 months of collagen protein supplementation, with or without exercise, affects basal and postprandial muscle protein synthesis (MPS) and the skeletal muscle metabolome in healthy older adults.
results_summary: The study found that collagen protein supplementation did not alter basal or postprandial MPS or the muscle metabolome compared to an isocaloric control. No significant differences were observed between collagen and other intervention groups.
population_specificity: Healthy older Danes (>65 years, 29 females/37 males).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent knowledge on the role of vitamins C and D, particularly their involvement in collagen synthesis and regulation, in the pathogenesis and treatment of periodontitis.
results_summary: Vitamin C was found to be crucial for collagen synthesis, with deficiency linked to periodontal ligament damage, while supplementation improved postoperative outcomes in periodontitis patients. Vitamin D reduced proinflammatory cytokines and regulated tooth mineral density, with supplementation associated with better nonsurgical treatment results.
population_specificity: Patients with periodontitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the existing evidence on collagenous gastritis (CG), including its clinical characteristics, endoscopic and histopathologic features, and treatment outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that most CG patients presented with anemia (61.4%) and abdominal discomfort (60.5%), with common endoscopic findings including gastric nodularity (60.2%) and erythema/erosions (26.1%). Clinical improvement was seen in 64.2% of cases, with treatments like iron supplementation (42%) and PPIs (30.7%) being most common.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with collagenous gastritis (CG).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the types of collagens available for joint health, their mechanisms of action, and the preclinical and clinical evidence supporting their safety and efficacy.
results_summary: The study found that native and hydrolyzed collagen have distinct mechanisms of action, with native collagen acting via immune-mediated pathways and hydrolyzed collagen providing bioactive peptides for chondroprotective effects. Preclinical and clinical studies support their safety and efficacy, though efficacy is linked to collagen's chemical structure.
population_specificity: Not specified (general joint health focus)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of collagen peptide (CPNS) containing Gly-Pro and Pro-Hyp on skin wrinkling, desquamation, elasticity, and hydration in aging human skin.
results_summary: The study found that daily intake of 1650 mg CPNS for 12 weeks improved skin health, including elasticity, hydration, and reduced wrinkling and desquamation in women aged 30-60.
population_specificity: Women aged 30-60 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of collagen supplementation as part of nutritional strategies during the rehabilitation phase of musculoskeletal injuries in elite athletes.
results_summary: The study found that collagen supplementation shows promising effects for rehabilitation in injured athletes, though further research is needed to confirm its efficacy. The abstract highlights a lack of clinical research in this area, with most evidence coming from reviews.
population_specificity: Elite athletes with musculoskeletal injuries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if collagen supplementation enhances the effects of high-impact exercise on bone turnover and whether increased exercise frequency benefits bone metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that daily high-impact exercise increased bone formation markers (P1NP), but collagen supplementation did not further enhance this effect. Bone resorption markers (CTX-I) were unaffected by exercise or collagen.
population_specificity: 14 healthy males (age 24 ± 4 y, BMI 22.0 ± 2.1 kg/m²)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 8 weeks of daily Shilajit supplementation (500 mg/day) increases circulating levels of Type 1 collagen, given its known effect on collagen synthesis gene expression.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results on whether Shilajit supplementation increased circulating collagen levels, only stating the study's purpose.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of low-molecular-weight collagen peptides for treating photoaged and dry skin.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study design suggests an investigation into collagen peptides' effects on skin aging and dryness.
population_specificity: Study participants with photoaged and dry skin (specific demographics not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the scientific foundation of RF therapy and its role in aesthetic dermatology, including its mechanisms and applications.
results_summary: The abstract discusses various RF systems, delivery methods, and their effects on skin and adipose tissue remodeling, but does not specifically address collagen outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus is on RF therapy in aesthetic dermatology).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether collagen peptide (CP) supplementation enhances functional, structural, and contractile adaptations in skeletal muscle compared to placebo during a 15-week resistance training program.
results_summary: CP supplementation led to greater increases in muscle volume (quadriceps, vastus medialis, total muscle) and twitch peak torque compared to placebo, though maximum strength improvements did not differ between groups. CP also enhanced the angle of pennation in the vastus medialis, suggesting improved muscle remodeling.
population_specificity: Young healthy males

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if glycine-rich collagen peptides (CP) could improve sleep quality in physically active men with self-reported sleep complaints.
results_summary: CP supplementation reduced awakenings and improved cognitive function but did not affect sleep quantity, latency, or efficiency. No differences were observed in core temperature, endocrine function, inflammation, or subjective sleepiness.
population_specificity: 13 athletic males (age 24 ± 4 years, training volume 7 ± 3 h·wk⁻¹) with sleep complaints.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether collagen peptide supplementation affects exercise-induced gastrointestinal stress, inflammation, and GI integrity.
results_summary: Collagen peptides did not significantly alter exercise-induced changes in inflammation, GI integrity, or subjective GI symptoms, though LPS levels were higher in the control group 2 hours post-exercise. No differences were observed in heart rate, perceived exertion, or cytokine levels between the collagen and control trials.
population_specificity: 20 volunteers (16 males, 4 females)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of nutrition, including collagen synthesis, in wound prevention, management, and treatment.
results_summary: The study highlights that malnutrition reduces collagen synthesis and tensile strength, impairing wound healing, and emphasizes the need for individualized nutritional interventions to improve outcomes.
population_specificity: Individuals with wounds or at risk of wound development.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of topical omega-3 in treating dry eye, including its effects on ocular surface staining, tear break-up time, and inflammatory markers.
results_summary: Topical omega-3 showed promising improvements in ocular surface staining and tear break-up time, mixed results for symptoms and meibomian gland dysfunction, and no effect on tear production. Animal studies supported these findings and indicated reduced inflammation.
population_specificity: Human studies included patients with dry eye disease, contact lens discomfort, and those undergoing corneal collagen crosslinking, as well as animal models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of oral hydrolyzed collagen in mitigating signs of skin aging.
results_summary: The study found that oral hydrolyzed collagen is well tolerated and can mitigate some signs of skin aging, based on numerous clinical trials. However, evidence on other dietary supplements like vitamins and plant extracts is lacking.
population_specificity: Predominantly female samples (specific details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of collagen peptide supplementation on connective tissue recovery, pain reduction, and improvements in strength and body composition, particularly when paired with resistance training.
results_summary: Collagen peptide supplementation was found to improve pain and function, upregulate metabolic pathways related to muscle and tendon growth, and enhance collagen synthesis and degradation. It also improved body composition and strength when combined with resistance training, likely due to bioactive peptides in the supplements.
population_specificity: Active and aging populations with connective tissue injuries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of selenium supplementation on bone turnover markers (including collagen-related markers like PINP and CTX) in older adults over short-term (6 months) and long-term (5 years) periods.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of selenium supplementation on collagen-related bone turnover markers (PINP, CTX) or other markers (OC, BALP) at either 6 months or 5 years, suggesting no impact on bone health in this population. The lack of effect may be due to participants' relatively replete baseline selenium status.
population_specificity: 481 Danish men and women aged 60-74 years.
effective_dosage: 100, 200, or 300 μg selenium as selenium-enriched yeast daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of water-soluble tomato concentrate (WSTC) on platelet apoptosis and oxidative stress in healthy middle-aged and elderly adults.
results_summary: WSTC increased serum total antioxidant capacity, decreased malondialdehyde levels, and attenuated platelet oxidative stress markers. It also inhibited platelet aggregation and activation induced by collagen or ADP without affecting adverse events.
population_specificity: Healthy middle-aged and elderly adults (n=52).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the roles of COMP in collagen assembly, ECM stability, and its involvement in various diseases, including skeletal disorders, malignancy, cardiovascular diseases, and tissue fibrosis.
results_summary: The study found that COMP is critical for collagen assembly and ECM stability, with distinct roles in different diseases. It may have therapeutic potential for osteoarthritis and aortic aneurysms but could pose risks like tissue fibrosis or cancer metastasis in other contexts.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary supplementation with a shilajit extract could attenuate bone loss in postmenopausal women with osteopenia by reducing oxidative stress, inflammation, and bone turnover.
results_summary: Shilajit extract supplementation dose-dependently attenuated bone mineral density loss, reduced bone turnover markers (CTX-1, BALP, RANKL), increased OPG, decreased oxidative stress (MDA, GSH), and lowered inflammation (hsCRP) compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women aged 45-65 years with osteopenia.
effective_dosage: 250 mg or 500 mg shilajit extract daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Crassocephalum rabens extract, particularly its active compound dLGG, could improve skin conditions such as elasticity, wrinkles, collagen content, brightness, and hydration in healthy individuals.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in skin elasticity, wrinkles, collagen content, brightness, and hydration in the treatment group compared to the placebo group, with notable statistical significance (p < 0.05 to p < 0.001).
population_specificity: 40 healthy volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of collagen supplementation on rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and osteoarthritis (OA) patients, focusing on immune response suppression as a potential therapeutic approach.
results_summary: The study found high adverse effects and low efficiency of collagen supplementation compared to routine treatments, with most studies having poor quality, making definitive conclusions on its benefits or harms impossible.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and osteoarthritis (OA).
effective_dosage: Intact and hydrolyzed collagen (specific dosages not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of collagen peptide supplementation (CPS) on cardiovascular disease (CVD)-related markers through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Pooled data from 12 RCTs showed that CPS significantly decreased fat mass (-1.21 kg; 95% CI: -2.13, -0.29), suggesting a positive effect on CVD-related markers. The study did not report adverse effects or other outcomes in detail.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract (likely general or mixed populations from the included RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether specific collagen peptides (SCP) combined with resistance training (RT) enhance tendinous and muscular properties compared to RT alone.
results_summary: SCP supplementation significantly increased tendon cross-sectional area (+11.0% vs. +4.7%) and muscle thickness (+7.3% vs. +2.7%) compared to placebo, with no significant difference in tendon stiffness or muscle strength between groups.
population_specificity: 40 healthy male volunteers (age 26.3 ± 4.0 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of solar-simulated UVR on human dermal ECM and the potential protective role of green tea catechins (GTCs) on collagen and elastic fiber networks.
results_summary: UVR exposure significantly reduced collagen and elastic fiber coverage in the dermis and altered specific ECM components. GTC supplementation specifically protected against UVR-induced changes in fibulin-5 but did not affect other ECM components.
population_specificity: 50 healthy white adults (Fitzpatrick skin type I-II) aged 18-65 years.
effective_dosage: GTCs 540 mg plus vitamin C 50 mg twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of glycine in the development and treatment of metabolic syndrome components, including its involvement in collagen production.
results_summary: The study found that glycine supplementation improves components of metabolic syndrome such as diabetes, obesity, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension, and that circulating glycine levels increase with interventions like lifestyle modification, exercise, and weight loss.
population_specificity: Subjects with metabolic syndrome and healthy individuals.
